Macroeconomic Background 1.1 Over the last decade, Chile has experienced one of the most sustained macroeconomic performances in Latin America. Since 1982, exports tripled and the economy grew for 11 consecutive years. From 1984 to 1994, driven by the remarkable annual growth rates in investments and exports, averaging 14.3 percent and 9.9 percent, respectively, GDP increased by an average annual rate of 6.8 percent. During the same period, inflation declined from 23 percent to 8.9 percent. At end-1994, Chile had a relatively small public sector (general government expenditures totalled 23.3 percent of GDP), high investment rates (25.6 percent of GDP), a strong reserve position, a relatively flexible labor code, and an open trade regime. 1.2 The steady resolve of successive Administrations to carry out a comprehensive reform program aimed at redefining the role of the state brought about the sound economic performance. Starting in the mid 1970s, Chile began reducing trade protection sharply, privatizing firms and restructuring public enterprises along commercial lines, decreasing Government subsidies, and decentralizing responsibilities to the municipal level. An innovative pension reform program, designed to increase domestic savings, offered social security payers access to newly established pension funds. 1.3 In 1992, the economy reached its highest growth rate (10.4 percent) in 27 years. Real 1993 GDP growth declined to 6.3 percent due to a deterioration in Chile's terms of trade, reflecting a 15 percent decline in international prices of its major exports (copper, paper products, fishmeal and fruit) and a restrictive monetary policy that had been adopted to cool the economy. A substantial rebound in copper prices, along with strong demand from Chile's markets turned the economy around in the second quarter of 1994. As a result, the trade balance improved and the current account deficit dropped to 0.9 percent of GDP in 1994. Chile's balance of payments continued to benefit from strong increases in capital inflows induced by prudent macroeconomic management, deep capital markets, and well- defined legal and regulatory frameworks. As a consequence, the Central Bank accumulated ample reserves, up to US$13 billion (equivalent to 9.8 months' imports) by end-1994, and the peso appreciated by 7.1 percent in nominal terms in 1994. While a restrictive monetary policy succeeded in reducing annual inflation to 8.9 percent in 1994, GDP growth slowed to 4.5 percent. As a result, unemployment increased to 6.5 percent, up from a record low 4.5 percent in 1993.

Agriculture in the Economy Policy Framework 1.4 The macroeconomic policy reforms of the mid-1980s, complemented by sectoral policy adjustments, liberalized domestic and foreign trade agricultural markets and eliminated distortions in the credit system. Most agricultural products have a uniform 11 percent tariff and are free of non-quantitative trade restrictions. Price bands for a few basic staples, i.e. wheat and sugar, minimize the destabilizing impact sharp changes in import prices could have on domestic production. Private banks provide credit to commercial farmers at real interest rates between 6.5 percent and 9 percent. Small farmers have access to a special credit line, whose funds are available at interest rates linked to the cost of money as determined by Central Bank operations. The current interest rate for small farmers is 7.5 percent in real terms. Performance 1.5 The agricultural sector contributes approximately 8 percent of GDP, employs 18 percent of the country's economically active population and generates 35 percent of its merchandise exports. Chile is a highly urbanized country, with under 15 percent of its 13.6 million inhabitants living in rural areas. Between 1983 and 1989, agricultural GDP (including forestry and fisheries) grew at an average annual rate of 5.8 percent, with export crops playing a leading role. Between 1989 and 1992, declining world prices for fruit and horticultural exports and decreased wheat production caused the annual agricultural growth rate to drop to 3.0 percent. During the past two years, the gradual appreciation of the peso has affected exports. Although agricultural export growth will continue, sector growth will be determined by the capacity of producers to improve productivity and orient their production towards highly profitable crops. 1.6 Within the sector, there are marked differences in performance and natural resource management among regions, crops and producers. Regional differences reflect agro-ecological variations. Among crops, contrasts are explained by diverse and dynamic market opportunities. The most pronounced differences in productivity and profitability are found between commercial and small farmers. Reconciliation of this duality, compounded by the diversity within the small farmer sector, ranging from those with agricultural potential to those with limited or no agricultural potential, will be this Government's most serious sectoral challenge.

Half of these were extremely poor - unable to satisfy their minimum food requirements. In 1992, while 80 percent of the poor were urban dwellers, the incidence of poverty in the rural areas (34 percent) was greater than in urban areas (30 percent). In the project area, covering Regions VI through VIII, the incidence of rural poverty was greater than 40 percent. In 1991, 84 percent of the country's poorest municipalities (comunas)2 were rural.3 The rural poor tend to be small farmers, older and having a lower education than the rest of the population. They are confronted by deteriorating soils and limited access to credit and critical social services. 1.8 Between 1990 and 1993, the Solidarity and Social Investment Fund (FOSIS) financed more than 2.100 projects, valued at US$34 million, to improve the welfare of the poorest sectors.4 Between 1990 and 1993, the national poverty level fell from 40 percent to 33 percent due to sustained economic growth, increased social expenditure and greater poverty alleviation investments. During that period, the incidence of urban poverty declined by 23.8 percent and rural incidence fell by 20 percent. However, poverty incidence in the project area decreased by less than 12 percent. The Chilean experience highlights the importance of sound macroeconomic and sectoral policies, complemented by a strong institutional framework with a skilled civil service. 1.21 The Bank has extended nine agricultural loans to Chile in the past four decades, totalling US$260.0 million. Early projects provided credit for modernization and expansion of agricultural infrastructure. Lessons from these are the value of (i) flexibility in project design; and (ii) beneficiary involvement. The project's flexible design allowed beneficiaries to specify project activities. -I. Characteristics of the Secano 16 Natural Resource Base and Land Use 2.1 The area of influence of the proposed project is within the dryland areas of the slopes of the Cordillera de la Costa [Coastal Mountain Range], known as respectively, the "Coastal" and "Inland" Secano. The entire Secano stretches from Region V to Region X (between parallels 320 20' and 420 30', S. Lat.), covering 5.7 million hectares. The project area of influence would incorporate Region VI to VIII, covering 3.5 million ha. This area covers four agro-ecological zones, with a climate that varies from mediterranean in the north to marine in the south and annual rainfall ranging from 350 mm, in the north, to 1,200 mm, towards the south. 2.2 Irrational use is degrading regional natural resources. Pasture area greatly exceeds the area suitable for such purpose, less than 5 percent of which is improved pasture. To avoid soil erosion, nearly 60 percent of the region should be under forest, yet only 10 percent is. In many areas, basic grains, fruit trees and table grapes, vegetables and flowers, are cultivated on soils ill-suited for these crops. 16.  - 12 - B. Development Potential and Constraints of the Small Farmer 2.17 The Secano's economic potential lies in the development of its forests and pastures. With sufficient capital, investing in these areas could represent important economic options for small farmers. Expanded irrigation could considerably increase crop production. Given the region's topography, storing water run-offs with small basins could irrigate several thousands of hectares. In those zones where irrigation is not feasible, production could be enhanced through cost-effective rainfed farming techniques. Production and productivity could be through land-intensive technologies which would reduce cultivated area, resulting in land use patterns more suited to the available natural resources. 2.18 The poor natural resource base is a serious constraint to improving the Secano's small farmers' household welfare. Farms are small with poor, fragile and degraded soils. Insufficient water constrains production increases, with rainfall concentrated in the period of least vegetative growth and disappearing during the period of crop ripening and pasture growth. In many ares, the limited coverage and poor condition of the irrigation system restrict the development of fruit, especially grape, production. In livestock production-oriented micro-regions with relatively scarce rainfall, poor irrigation limits crop production for home consumption. Throughout the Secano, training and technical assistance could increase efficiency of on-farm irrigation. 2.19 Poverty limits small farmers' ability to adjust production patterns and cultural practices in response to natural resource endowments and economic incentives. Household survival dictates that highest priority be given to subsistence crop production, with little regard for soil type or condition. Frequently, farmers need to cultivate steep slopes, resulting in soil degradation and erosion. Poverty increases small farmers' reluctance to experiment with novel cultivation practices, as such modification could fail, affect not only the farm operations, but also the household's livelihood. 2.20 There is a dearth of ecologically viable production systems adapted to the special Secano conditions. Despite INDAP's recent program shift towards subsistence farmers, its coverage in the Secano is inadequate, dispersed and crop-specific. Poor infrastructure, including post-harvest storage, processing and marketing, and all-weather rural roads restrain regional development by impeding competitive market formations. Finally, deficient social services, such as health. education, drinking water and electricity, depress the welfare of the rural poor.

Origin and Rationale for Bank Involvement 3.1 Despite its substantial agro-forestry potential, the Secano is economically depressed, with the highest incidence of rural poverty in Chile.28 The region has remained beyond the reach of both the national economic growth and most social programs. Targeted programs, together with economic growth, are needed to alleviate regional rural poverty. 3.2 The project's strategy would increase economic returns to land by promoting soil conservation and production technologies capable of sustaining increased production and income. Assistance would be given to farmers in the design and execution of production systems compatible with land capabilities and natural resource conservation practices. In zones with sufficient water resources, the project would promote technically and economically viable irrigation works, crop intensification and diversification. The project would: (i) establish cultivated pastures or improved natural pasture management; and (ii) create forest plantations and enrich existing natural forests. Project-financed investments would generate sufficient additional income to allow farmers to invest in their farms, on better lowland soils, pastures and forestry. 3.3 The project's poverty alleviation strategy would combine on- and off-farm activities to reverse natural resource deterioration and increase household income and welfare on a sustainable basis. The relative importance of one type of activity over another would depend on the beneficiaries' socio-economic characteristics and survival tactics. The strategy would generate employment. thereby increasing incomes for under-employed rural families and reducing their need to abuse natural resources. While beneficiaries would select project off-farm activities, likely activities include handicrafts. cottage industries and small agro- industries. Beneficiaries would be assisted in the preparation of employment-generating investment proposals and, subsequently, provided resources for their implementation. Project-financed training, complementing the development of off-farm activities, would equip beneficiaries with skills for non-agricultural labor markets and developing micro-enterprises. The project would rehabilitate rural feeder roads and address community-identified marketing bottlenecks. 3.4 The project's poverty alleviation activities would address the needs of the Secano's three small farmer types (see para 2.16). For Type I, households which draw most of their income from on-farm production, the project would improve production patterns. cultural practices and natural resource management. For Type II, households which combine on-farn production with off-farm activities, the project would support the development of small-scale forest plantations to improve natural resource management and appreciate land assets. The project would improve natural resource management, emphasizing soil and water conservation, upgrade pastures and grasslands, and reforest and enrich native woodlands. 2. Prior to colonization, the northern Secano was covered with espino savanna, and its southern regions, were covered with sclerophytic vegetation and nothofagus forest. In the early 1700s, deforestation initiated and accelerated after 1760 with wheat area expansion. By 1900, most forests from the moderately sloping areas had been removed. Two centuries of poor resource management has deforested over 90% of the area. Even the remaining woodland patches, on the remote steep slopes, have been degraded by extraction and overgrazing. 3. Soils are severely eroded, suffering structural and fertility losses. In areas with greater rainfall, some farmland has been converted into eucalyptus and pine plantations. Large to medium farmers cultivate the irrigated valleys. While poor farmers (the project's beneficiary group) over-cultivate and over-graze their small plots on eroded slopes. Without targeted efforts to improve their conditions, small farmers will be forced to continue to deteriorate their natural resources to the point of abandonment. Environmental Impact Assessment 4.  - 114 - Annex 0 CHILE SECANO RURAL POVERTY ALLEVIATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PROJECT Economic Analysis A. Benefits and Costs from Natural Resource Management and Sustainable Agricultural Development and Rural Infrastructure Components 1. The project would improve the production patterns of more than 22,000 ha of 1,345 small farmers (out of 2,845 within the seven selected micro-regions; see para. 13) and develop sustainable small farmer production systems consistent with land capabilities. Area under annual crops would be reduced by at least 3,400 ha, concentrated on better soils and diversified into higher-value crops. The wheat area is conservatively estimated to decline from 2,750 ha to about 930 ha. Once new production systems are fully developed and farmers no longer rely on their on-farm production for subsistence, wheat production in the project area would likely disappear. Project-financed irrigation works on 1,500 ha would increase cropping intensities. On 5,000 non-irrigable ha, the project would introduce rainfed cultivation practices aimed at proper soil and water conservation. 2. Additionally, the project would increase area under grapes, the Secano's most profitable crop, to about 2,100 ha, improve vineyard cultivation practices to avoid soil erosion and introduce grape varieties with higher market value. Land released from crop cultivation would be directed to pastures and forestry. At pilot project completion, it is expected that there would be over 6,100 ha of properly-managed natural pastures, 3,570 ha of improved pastures, 3,400 ha of silvo-pastoral production, 4,500. ha of planted forest and 100 ha of woodland renovation. 3. By promoting commodities for which there is strong domestic and export demand, the project would integrate a relatively marginal region into the main economy. The project area is expected to produce annually over US$2.6 million of vegetables and pulses for domestic markets. In addition, US$3.0 million of wine and nearly US$1.0 million of lamb would be produced, an important share of which would be exported. Additionally, project-promoted forestry activities would produce US$36.0 million of roundwood or posts for local fruit industry, and US$27.0 million of pulpwood for the pulp industry, throughout the project's life.
 - 115 - Annex 0 B. Internal Economic Rate of Return (IERR) 4. Natural resources and rural infrastructure components. The internal economic rate of return for these components is 20.7%. Working hypotheses of likely beneficiary choices were developed to estimate the internal economic rate of return of the project's natural resource management and sustainable agricultural and rural infrastructure components. 5. This estimate incorporates the costs of on-farm investments (US$13.0 million), technology transfer (US$2.0 million), rural infrastructure (US$2.4 million) and the Project Technical Unit (US$1.1 million). The IERR includes economic benefits derived from: (i) crop productivity gains, resulting from improved practices; (ii) crop diversification into higher-valued crops; (iii) decreased production costs; and (iv) reduced marketing margins, due to better rural infrastructure were taken into account and applied to indicative farm models, representative of project beneficiaries in the Secano.' This estimate is conservative, since it does not consider the benefits accruing from reduced soil run-off and erosion. Furthermore, the analysis did not capture "without project" productivity loses (as a project benefit) due to declining soil fertility. 6. Off-farm investment component: As beneficiaries would determine which activities would be financed, an ex-anzte estimation of costs and benefits of the off-farm investment component can be made by analyzing a sample of likely off-farm projects. The preparation team found that most proposals would be small, ranging between US$25,000 and US$100,000, and economically highly feasible, having estimated internal economic rates of return above 25%. Since only technically and economically sound proposals would receive project finance, this component would likely increase the project's internal economic rate of return. To ensure economic viability, a threshold of a minimum estimated internal economic rate of return would be applied as a selection criteria to sub-project proposals. 7. Technical assistance, institutional strengthening and training components: Technical assistance would help beneficiaries execute off-farm poverty alleviation activities and support Government decentralization efforts through institutional strengthening. The economic impact of these interventions was not evaluated as the portfolio of off-farm investments would be defined at implementation by the beneficiaries and the benefits arising from facilitating rural municipalities in the execution of their responsibilities, as well as beneficiary training, are not quantifiable. 8. Research and studies components: These components' benefits would stem from: (i) research for increasing the economic development of the Secano, given its special social and ecological circumstances; (ii) an improved Governrment natural resource management monitoring system; and (iii) an analysis of local commodity markets. The internal economic rate of return used base costs plus physical contingencies, less taxes and price contingencies. The opportunity cost of capital was 12%. 10. Pricing. The rate of exchange of the Chilean peso is determined in the open market. As there are no major trade restrictions, domestic prices tend to correspond to border economic values. For the economic analysis, the criteria and assumptions used by the Ministry of Planning (MIDEPLAN) were applied. Border prices were used for all tradeables produced by the project, based on the projections of MIDEPLAN and exporting firms (which, for wheat and maize, are lower than Bank projections). A conversion factor of 0.90 was used for inputs and machinery. 11. Labor. While the project would increase on-farm and off-farm employment in the selected micro-regions, unemployment and under-employment would not be eliminated. Therefore, MIDEPLAN's labor cost assumptions were used, including unskilled and semi- skilled labor shadow prices, estimated at 0.66 of the market wage rate. The market rate for skilled labor was assumed to reflect its opportunity cost. 12. Yields. In the without-project situation, yields were assumed to remain constant, although there are indications that, as a result of declining soil fertility, yields have been declining. 13. Adoption Rates. During the first year of implementation, project participation of between 5% and 10% of the small farmers in the selected micro-regions is expected. Participation would increase in subsequent years, until the project year five, when an estimated 47 percent of small farmers in the selected micro-region would participate in the project. Relatively high participation rates are expected due to the: (i) farmers' interest expressed in the participatory diagnosis carried out during project preparation; (ii) attractive incentive packages offered; (iii) relatively low risk the production packages represent to farmers' subsistence; and (iv) high probability of successful implementation due to system- oriented technical assistance. Moreover, the project's flexibility in implementation would allow for design adjustments to address constraints to farmers' adoption. 14. Farmers' Income. The project is expected to more than double family on-farm income. Nevertheless, given their impoverishment, even with these on -farm income gains, a significant proportion of the families would continue to live in poverty. Farmners with off-

Inappropriate cultivation practices, combined with soil fertility losses and low natural pasture yields, depress Secano most on-farm income below the "extreme poverty line". According to MIDEPLAN, the annual per capita "poverty line" income is US$723 and the "extreme poverty line" income is US$362.2 Applying these benchmarks,3 most farmers in the project area have on-farm incomes substantially below the "extreme poverty line". Only small farmers (i) with farms larger than 20 ha4 (less than 25% of the total) and/or (ii) engaged in vineyard and intensive horticulture cultivation have higher on-farm incomes. In the absence of remedial action, the generally low on-farm Secano incomes would decline further due to the deterioration of the region's natural resources. 16. Applying indicative farm models' to assess the project's impact, farms with vineyards would obtain the highest income levels, about twice the poverty level. Farms, combining agricultural (with 0.5-0.8 ha under irrigation) and livestock production, are likely to earn an on-farm income ranging between the poverty line to twice the poverty line. On-farm income of farms, combining agro-livestock production with silvo-pastoral activities, would approximate the poverty line. 17. On-farm income earnings for farms in areas with highly degraded natural resources would be derived primarily from forestry, reserving agricultural production for home consumption. Although the project would increase on-farn incomes, the level would remain below the "extreme poverty line". Therefore, the project would increase these farmers' incomes through the PFAP-financed off-farm investments. Additionally, the project would generate annual employment for 1,000 wage laborers in agriculture, livestock and forestry. D. Sensitivity Analysis 18. doc.repnme: Chile - Secano Rural Poverty Alleviation and Natural Resource Management Project
doc.abstracts: The project will address rural poverty and natural resource degradation, mutually reinforcing problems, through the development and validation of comprehensive strategies which achieve sustainable rural poverty and economic growth through increased family income and improved natural resource management. The Secano's diverse and fragile resource base, along with a lack of effective regional poverty alleviation strategies, argues for a project which can validate alternative development approaches. The heterogeneity of Secano conditions call for a micro-regional approach starting with pilot-scale sub-projects in representative areas to test the technological, social and institutional actions considered to be most likely to succeed. The project will develop viable strategies which will: a) improve natural resource management to reverse soil degradation and establish sustainable production systems; and b) expand off-farm economic activities and improve economic infrastructure to diversify income sources and boost regional development. The results of the micro-regional endeavors will serve as economically viable and environmentally sound models for possible eventual larger government-funded programs, covering a greater area of Secano. Project components will be: a) natural resource management and sustainable development; b) off-farm poverty alleviation; c) support services; d) technical assistance; e) land title regularization; and f) studies.
